The rain over Abbotsford had a particular weight to it, a heaviness that felt less like water and more like a liquid sigh from the bruised belly of the sky. Alistair Finch felt it soak into the shoulders of his flannel shirt, a familiar dampness that smelled of wet earth and cedar mulch. He stood in the open doorway of his largest greenhouse, a long, cathedral-like structure of sweating polycarbonate panels and moss-furred wooden beams. Finch’s Foliage, the sign out by the road read, its hand-painted letters peeling like birch bark. It was his world, this pocket of curated life nestled against the rumpled green flank of Sumas Mountain. Inside, the air was a warm, humid cocktail of petrichor, blooming jasmine, and the dark, fertile breath of a thousand bags of topsoil.

Alistair was, by his own quiet admission, a warlock. Not the sort you read about in paperbacks with lurid covers, all swirling capes and crackling bolts of amethyst light. His magic was the colour of soil, the texture of a leaf’s vein, the slow, patient persistence of a root finding its way through packed clay. He could coax a recalcitrant orchid into a shocking display of magenta blooms with a murmured word, could feel the thirst of a potted ficus from across the yard, could, on a good day, sense the intricate latticework of mycelium that stitched the whole Fraser Valley together beneath his worn work boots. He was a warlock of loam and leaf, a master of the small, green, and growing. His ambitions were appropriately sized: to produce the hardiest tomato starts in the Lower Mainland and maybe, one day, afford a new transmission for his rust-pocked Tacoma.

He was humming a half-forgotten tune, repotting a gangly monstera, when the sky outside the greenhouse door went dark. Not the rolling-in-grey of an afternoon storm, but a sudden, sharp eclipse. Alistair looked up, hands still caked in dirt. A cloud of starlings, a living vortex of thousands of birds, was swirling directly overhead. It was a murmuration, but it was unlike any he had ever seen. There was a terrifying intelligence to its shape. The birds moved not with the fluid chaos of nature but with the deliberate strokes of a calligrapher’s brush. The cloud thickened, contracted, then expanded into a single, stark word against the pale grey sky: FINCH.

His name.

Alistair’s breath hitched. The air in the greenhouse suddenly felt thin, stolen. He stumbled back a step, knocking over a stack of terracotta pots that shattered on the concrete floor with a sound like breaking teeth. The starlings held the shape for a full ten seconds, a stark, black banner of his own identity, before dissolving back into a frantic, chaotic spiral and vanishing over the mountain. Silence rushed back in, thick and ringing. The only sound was the patter of the rain and the frantic, drumming beat of his own heart. He told himself it was a trick of the light, a bizarre coincidence, the kind of thing you’d see on a sketchy YouTube channel sandwiched between alien abductions and proofs that the world was flat. He was a man who communed with ferns; he did not receive omens from the sky. It was absurd.

He knelt, his knees cracking, and began to gather the sharp, rust-coloured shards of the broken pots. His hands were shaking. He swept the pieces into a dustpan, his movements jerky and inefficient. He needed to get back to work. He had an order of winter pansies to fill. He had irrigation lines to check. He had a world to ignore. But as he stood and turned back to his potting bench, he froze.

It was there. On the rough, soil-strewn planks of the bench, precisely where his trowel and pot of soil had been moments before. A box. It was small, no bigger than a shoebox for a child’s pair of shoes, and made of a dark, indeterminate wood. There was no grain to it, no knots, no seams. It was a solid, featureless block of shadow, cool and smooth to the touch, absorbing the light rather than reflecting it. It hadn't been there a minute ago. He would have seen it. He knew every square inch of this bench, every stain, every gouge. The box was an impossibility, an alien object in the heart of his sanctuary. He circled it like a wary animal, his gardener’s senses screaming at this sterile, lifeless thing amidst so much life. There was no lock, no lid, no obvious way to open it.

He reached out a tentative finger, the nail still rimmed with dirt, and touched its surface. It was cold, a deep, cellular cold that seemed to leech the warmth from his fingertip. He tried to nudge it. It wouldn't move. It was as if it were a part of the bench itself, as if it had grown there. Panic, cold and sharp, began to prickle at the back of his neck. His own quiet magic, the gentle green force he used to encourage and nurture, lapped against the box and dissipated, like waves against a stone cliff. This thing was anathema to his world.

A different instinct took over, something older and deeper than the patient magic of plants. It was a flicker of will, the part of him that was not just a gardener but a warlock, a manipulator of the unseen threads. He focused on the box, not with a request, but with a command. *Open.* The word was a silent thought, but it had the force of a shout in his mind. For a moment, nothing happened. Then, with a soundless sigh, a line of pure light appeared down the middle of the box, and it fell open into two perfect halves.

There was no puff of smoke, no spectral voice. The contents were crushingly simple. Nestled on a bed of what looked like black velvet lay a single, perfectly smooth river stone, grey and unassuming. It looked like any of a million stones he’d skipped across the Fraser River as a boy. Disappointment was a bizarre and unwelcome flavour in his mouth. All that celestial drama for a rock? He reached in and picked it up.

The moment his skin touched the stone, the world fell away. The greenhouse, the rain, the smell of jasmine—all of it vanished, replaced by a torrent of images and sensations that crashed through his mind. He saw a city of glass towers weeping black sludge. He saw fields of wheat turning to dust and blowing away on a foul wind. He saw oceans choked with a greasy, rainbow-coloured algae. And he saw a man. A tall figure in robes the colour of a dying fire, his face obscured by shadow, standing atop a ziggurat of cracked concrete and twisted rebar. A miasma of power rolled off him, a power that felt like Alistair’s own, but twisted, corrupted, turned inward on itself until it had curdled into something monstrous.

And then came the smell. It wasn’t just in his mind; it was in his nostrils, real and suffocating. It was the smell of a forgotten refrigerator, of meat left too long in the sun, of sulfurous swamp gas and deep, abiding rot. It was a stench of profound and ancient decay, a foulness so absolute it felt like a physical blow. It was the smell of the man in the vision, the signature of his power, a nauseating perfume of corruption that clung to the very fabric of the reality he was unmaking.

A voice, not of sound but of pure concept, bloomed in the core of his being. *The balance is broken. A rot has taken root. His name is Vex, and he would turn the garden to a charnel house. You are a tender of the green. The world is your garden now. Weed it, or watch everything die.*

Alistair gasped and fell backwards, the connection breaking. He landed hard on the concrete floor, the river stone clattering from his grasp. He was back in his greenhouse. The air was sweet with jasmine again, but the memory of the stench was a ghost in his sinuses. He scrambled away from the stone, crab-walking backwards until his back hit a stack of potting soil bags. He sat there, breathing in ragged gulps of the clean, humid air, trying to scour the phantom smell from his memory. Vex. A warlock who stank of his own corrupted soul. A world-breaker. And him? A gardener. A man who talked to plants.

"No," he whispered to the silent rows of ferns and fiddle-leaf figs. "Absolutely not." This was a mistake. They’d picked the wrong Finch. There had to be other Finches. Heroic Finches. Finches who knew how to fight things that weren't aphids or powdery mildew. He got to his feet, his legs unsteady. He picked up the offending grey stone, his fingers recoiling slightly from its unnatural smoothness. He marched to the door of the greenhouse, his jaw set, and with all his might, he hurled the stone out into the rain-swept yard. It sailed in a high arc and disappeared into a thicket of overgrown rhododendrons.

He felt a ridiculous surge of triumph. Problem solved. Invitation declined. He was Alistair Finch, purveyor of fine foliage, and that was all he was going to be. He turned back to his work, his hands still trembling, and resolutely ignored the black, empty box on his bench. He would not be a hero. He would not "weed the world." He had pansies to pot, and that was that. He reached into his pocket for the small, worn knife he used to slice open bags of soil. His fingers closed not around the familiar wooden handle, but around the impossible, preternatural smoothness of a small, grey river stone.Alistair’s heart gave a painful lurch, a frantic bird beating against the cage of his ribs. He dropped the stone as if it were a hot coal, his hand flying back to his pocket, patting the empty denim frantically. It had been there. He had felt it. The weight, the impossible smoothness. He looked at the grey stone lying on the damp concrete floor, then back at his empty hand, his mind refusing to connect the two points. It was a sleight-of-hand trick performed by the universe, a piece of cosmic misdirection. He refused to be the audience. With a guttural sound of pure frustration, he snatched the stone up, marched to the far end of the long greenhouse, and wrenched open a small ventilation window set high in the wall. He threw the stone with all the force his shoulder could muster, not just into the yard, but aiming for the dense, dark woods that bordered his property. It vanished into the deepening twilight with a satisfying finality.

He slammed the vent shut, the polycarbonate rattling in its frame, and stood there, panting, his forehead pressed against the cool, damp panel. He would not check his pocket. He would not. It was a rule, a desperate pact he made with himself in that moment. If he didn't check, it couldn't be there. Reality was a matter of perspective, and he was choosing the one where he was just a nursery owner with a bad back and a rusty truck. He took a deep, calming breath, filling his lungs with the familiar, comforting scent of damp soil and chlorophyll. He felt the gentle thrum of his own magic settle, the quiet, green hum of life reasserting itself around him. See? All was well. He turned, a fragile sense of control returning, and took a single step back toward his potting bench. A faint, tell-tale clink came from his jacket pocket. It was the sound of the stone settling against the small metal button on his pocket flap.

A desperate, ragged laugh escaped his lips. It was a sound with no humour in it, thin and sharp. The panic was no longer a prickle; it was a flood, cold and absolute. This thing, this messenger stone, was a burr, a parasite. It had attached itself to him. His previous attempts to discard it were like trying to throw away his own shadow. Fine. If he couldn't get rid of it, he would unmake it. He stormed out of the greenhouse into the drizzling rain, not even flinching as the cold water ran down his face and neck. He stomped across the muddy yard to his workshed, a dilapidated lean-to filled with rusting tools and the ghosts of projects half-finished. He flicked on the bare bulb, which cast long, dancing shadows, and grabbed the heaviest tool he owned: a short-handled sledgehammer with a three-pound head, used for driving fence posts into stubborn ground. He marched back to the greenhouse, the hammer feeling like a righteous sceptre in his grip. He was a man of loam and leaf, but he knew how to break things.

He placed the small, grey stone on the solid concrete floor, a sacrificial offering on a brutalist altar. He ignored the black, featureless box that still sat open on his bench, a silent, judging spectator. He ignored the rain, which now seemed to be tapping at the roof with a new, insistent rhythm. He raised the sledgehammer high over his head, his muscles screaming with the unaccustomed strain, and brought it down with a roar of pure, terrified defiance. He expected a crack, a shattering, a puff of dust. What he got was a deafening *CLANG* of metal on something infinitely harder, a sound that vibrated up the wooden handle and into the bones of his arms, making his teeth ache. The hammerhead, made of solid, forged steel, had a fresh, crescent-shaped dent in its face. The river stone was utterly, completely, impossibly unmarked. It hadn't even moved. And as the ringing in his ears subsided, Alistair noticed something else. A faint, cloying smell on the air. It was the smell from the vision, the smell of rot and decay, faint but undeniable, a foul whisper winding its way through the sweet perfume of his greenhouse.

That was it. That was the moment his denial shattered like the terracotta pots. The smell. It wasn't a memory anymore. It was here. It was a pollutant in his sanctuary, an invasive species in his carefully tended world. He couldn't throw the problem away. He couldn't smash it into submission. It was real, and it was seeping into his life whether he wanted it to or not. The sledgehammer slid from his nerveless fingers and clattered to the floor. He sank to his knees, the fight draining out of him, replaced by a vast, hollow weariness. He was a gardener. His job was to tend, to nurture, to help things grow. The vision had told him as much. *You are a tender of the green. The world is your garden now. Weed it.* He had been given the most horrific weeding job in history. He looked at the stone, no longer with anger, but with a grim, weary resignation. He was Alistair Finch, a warlock of loam and leaf. And apparently, his ambitions had just been resized.

Slowly, his joints protesting, he reached out and picked up the stone. This time, he didn't flinch. He held it in his palm, studying its smooth, grey surface, feeling its strange, dense weight. He closed his eyes, not trying to command it, but to listen. He let his own quiet, green magic flow, not against it, but towards it, a tentative greeting. *Alright,* he thought, the word a silent surrender offered up to the universe. *Show me. Show me where to start.* The moment the thought formed, the stone grew warm in his hand, a pleasant, living heat. The vision did not return. There was no torrent of apocalyptic images, no phantom stench of decay. Instead, a single, clear image bloomed behind his eyelids, sharp and detailed as a photograph. It was a place. An old, forgotten corner of a city library, smelling of dust and paper and lemon polish. Rows of leather-bound books, a green-shaded reading lamp casting a pool of warm light, and on a small, wooden table, a single, enormous book bound in what looked like bark. The spine, in faded gold leaf, was stamped with a single, intricate symbol: a serpent coiled around the taproot of a great tree. The vision held for a moment, clear as day, then faded, leaving him with the lingering scent of old paper and the echo of profound silence. He opened his eyes, the grey stone now just a stone again in his palm. It wasn't a battle plan, but it was a breadcrumb. It was a starting point.The night passed in a blur of fretful half-sleep, punctuated by the phantom scent of rot and the imagined weight of the stone in his pocket. He woke before dawn, the habit of a lifetime, to a world washed clean by the night’s rain. The sky was the colour of pearl, and the air was crisp and cool. For a moment, standing in his small kitchen with a mug of coffee warming his hands, things felt normal. He could see his greenhouses from the window, their polycarbonate skins beaded with moisture, their interiors holding the soft, green promise of a new day. It was a lie, but it was a comforting one. He finished his coffee, the bitter heat a familiar anchor, before forcing himself to move. There was a rhythm to his life he couldn't abandon, a litany of small duties that kept the world turning, his own small world at least.

He spent the first hour of daylight on autopilot, his body moving through its ingrained routine while his mind skittered around the edges of his new reality. He checked the propagation trays, misting the delicate fern spores and the tiny, hopeful heads of new succulents. He consolidated an order of Japanese maples for a landscaping company in Chilliwack, his hands tying twine and wrapping root balls with an efficiency born of twenty years of practice. All the while, the stone was a dense, knowing presence in his pocket, and the featureless black box sat on the passenger seat of his Tacoma, a silent accusation. He had wrapped it in an old burlap sack, as if hiding it from sight could somehow lessen its reality. He was stalling, he knew, clinging to the familiar shoreline of his life before wading into the deep, cold water that awaited. The library. The book. The serpent and the root. It felt like a fever dream, but the stone in his pocket was undeniably real.

The drive into Vancouver was a slow, grinding ordeal. The Tacoma’s transmission whined a mournful protest every time it was forced to shift, a constant, mechanical reminder of the small, manageable problems he used to think were important. He drove through the patchwork of the Fraser Valley, past dairy farms and fields of corn stubble, a landscape he knew as intimately as the back of his own hand. But today he saw it through a new lens, a paranoid filter. Was the algae on that ditch pond a little too vibrant? Was the browning on those distant cedar trees a natural seasonal shift or the first touch of the decay he had been shown? The rot. The very idea felt like a contaminant in his mind, turning the beautiful, familiar world into a place of potential menace. He was a man who understood blight, rust, and fungus on a botanical level; this was something else entirely, a spiritual sickness he had no tools to diagnose.

The Vancouver Public Library rose from the city grid like a modern-day coliseum, a structure of granite and glass that felt a world away from the moss-furred beams of his greenhouse. The sheer scale of it was intimidating, a monument to a different kind of knowledge than the tactile, earthy wisdom he possessed. He found a parking spot deep in the concrete guts of the building and sat for a long moment with the engine off, the ticking of the cooling metal the only sound. He was a man in muddy work boots and a faded flannel shirt, carrying a magical rock and a cursed box, about to go hunting for a book of secrets in a temple of civic order. The absurdity of it was a physical weight. With a deep sigh that did little to calm the frantic energy in his chest, he grabbed the burlap-wrapped box, locked his truck, and walked toward the entrance, feeling like an imposter with every step.

Inside, the library was a hushed hive of activity. The air smelled of paper and floor polish and the faint, clean scent of the city’s rain on a hundred coats. Alistair felt profoundly out of place, his boots seeming to echo on the polished floors, his work-worn clothes a stark contrast to the urban attire of the students and office workers around him. He didn’t know where to start. The vision had been clear on the *what*, but vague on the *where*. He found a relatively secluded corner on the third floor, behind a shelf of oversized cartography books, and took a fortifying breath. He pulled the smooth, grey stone from his pocket. It felt cool and inert. Closing his eyes, he held it in his palm and focused, not on the apocalyptic horror, but on the image of the book. He didn't issue a command, but a question. *Where are you?*

The guidance came not as an image, but as a subtle, physical pull, an invisible string tugging gently at the hand holding the stone. It was a clear, directional impulse. *Up*. He opened his eyes and followed the feeling, past silent study carrels and rows upon rows of silent knowledge. The pull led him to a grand, curving staircase and then up again, to the higher, quieter levels of the library. The sensation grew stronger as he approached a set of heavy wooden doors with a discreet brass plaque that read: *Special Collections & Rare Books*. The air here felt different, older. The pull guided him through the doors into a hushed, climate-controlled room where a stern-looking woman with sharp glasses sat behind a large oak desk. And beyond her, through a glass partition, he saw it: a reading room filled with heavy wooden tables, each with a green-shaded lamp, exactly as it had been in his vision.

He approached the desk, his heart thumping a nervous rhythm against his ribs. The librarian looked up, her gaze taking in his damp shirt and the faint smudges of dirt on his jeans with an expression of mild, professional skepticism. "Can I help you?" she asked, her voice as crisp as old parchment. Alistair’s well-practiced lie evaporated on his tongue. The truth was impossible, but a fabrication felt equally doomed. He swallowed, the sound loud in the stillness. "I'm... looking for a particular book," he began, his voice rougher than he intended. "I don't have a title, or an author." The librarian’s eyebrow arched. "That could be a challenge. Do you have anything else to go on?" He hesitated, then plunged ahead. "It's bound in a material that looks like bark. And the spine has a symbol on it. In gold. A snake, coiled around the main root of a tree."

The librarian’s expression shifted from skepticism to a flicker of something else—guarded curiosity. She stared at him for a long moment, her eyes searching his face. "That is a very specific description for a book you don't know the title of," she said slowly. "My grandfather," Alistair lied, the falsehood coming to him in a rush of desperate inspiration. "He was a botanist. An eccentric one. He described it to me years ago, told me it was a foundational text. Said if I ever needed to understand the... the deep connections in the natural world, I should find it." It was a flimsy story, but it was threaded with just enough of his own truth to sound almost plausible. The librarian considered his story, her gaze unwavering. "One moment," she said, and turned to her computer terminal. Her fingers flew across the keyboard with silent efficiency. After a minute of typing, she stopped, her eyes fixed on the screen. Without looking at him, she said, "The text you are describing is likely the *Arborium Geographica*. It is not a book that is requested often. Please fill out this request form and I will have it brought to you. And you will need to leave your bag here." She gestured to the burlap sack he'd placed on the floor. He could only nod, his hands trembling slightly as he took the form.He slid into the hard wooden chair at one of the designated reading tables, the silence of the room pressing in on him. The librarian—Ms. Sterling, according to the small silver nameplate on her desk—disappeared into a secure-looking room behind her. Alistair was left alone with the low hum of the climate control and the unnerving weight of his own ignorance. He was surrounded by the accumulated, catalogued knowledge of generations, yet the one piece of information he desperately needed was locked in a book he’d only seen in a vision. He resisted the urge to fidget, to drum his dirt-stained fingers on the polished wood. Instead, he folded his hands in his lap, the smooth, dense weight of the messenger stone a constant reminder in his pocket, and tried to look like a man who belonged there, a visiting scholar, and not a terrified nurseryman being blackmailed by the cosmos.

After what felt like an eternity, Ms. Sterling returned. She wasn't carrying the book. She was pushing a small, padded library cart, and resting on its velvet-lined top was a volume so perfectly aligned with his vision it stole the air from his lungs. It was large and thick, bound not in leather but in a dark, textured material that was unmistakably bark, whorled and ridged like that of an ancient arbutus tree. The faint, faded gold of the coiled serpent and taproot seemed to shimmer in the low light. The librarian handled it with a reverence that bordered on the clinical, using white cotton gloves to lift it from the cart and place it on a cushioned book cradle in front of him.

"The *Arborium Geographica*," she said, her voice a low murmur that still carried across the silent room. "You will wear the provided gloves. You will not mark the pages. You will not lean on the book. You may take notes with the provided pencil and paper only. It is not to leave this table. Am I understood?" Alistair could only nod, his mouth dry. She placed a pair of white cotton gloves, a sharpened pencil, and a few sheets of thick, cream-coloured paper beside the cradle, then retreated to her desk. He knew, without looking, that he was being watched. Her professional surveillance felt as potent as a security camera. With hands that felt clumsy and foreign in the cotton gloves, he reached out and opened the cover.

The book did not smell of old paper. It smelled of deep earth after a long rain, of moss, of crushed leaves and distant ozone. The pages were not paper at all, but impossibly thin, semi-translucent sheets of pressed flora, each one a delicate mosaic of leaf skeletons, fibres, and preserved petals. And the text… it was a confounding mix. Some of it was in an archaic, spidery Latin he could barely parse, but interwoven with it were diagrams that looked less like writing and more like botanical drawings of impossible plants. There were maps, too, but they depicted no coastlines or mountain ranges he recognized. They were swirling, intricate webs of lines, glowing with a faint, residual energy, like the phosphorescent trails left by disturbed algae in a midnight sea. It was a geography of life itself.

He flipped through the delicate, rustling pages, a sense of profound awe warring with his rising panic. This was a language he understood, not in its specifics, but in its soul. It was a codex of the magic he himself practiced, writ large and ancient. But it was too vast, a whole world of information when he needed a single street address. He had no time to learn this language. He glanced at Ms. Sterling’s desk. She was pretending to read, but her posture was rigid, attentive. He needed a key. Slipping one hand into his pocket, his gloved fingers feeling clumsy, he pulled out the smooth river stone. The moment it was out in the open air of the room, he felt it grow subtly warm against the cotton. He took a chance. Shielding the motion with his body, he removed one glove and placed the bare stone directly onto the center of a swirling map of gossamer lines.

The effect was instantaneous and breathtaking. The page lit up from within. The faint lines of the map flared into vibrant emerald green, pulsing with a slow, steady rhythm, like a living, breathing circulatory system. It was the mycelial network, the deep, secret web he could sometimes feel under his boots, now laid bare and brilliant before his eyes. It was the latticework of life for the entire region, a map of the valley's soul. He could see a particularly bright nexus of lines that he instinctively knew was his own property, his greenhouse a tiny, glowing heart pumping life into the surrounding network. But as the awe filled him, the memory of the stench returned, and with it, the cold purpose of his mission. He focused his will, not with a word, but with the concept of the rot, the foulness he had smelled, the corruption of Vex. *Show me the sickness.*

The brilliant green map flickered. On the eastern edge of the glowing web, a stain appeared. It was a creeping, oily blackness, shot through with veins of a colour like dried blood. It wasn't just covering the green lines; it was eating them, causing the vibrant emerald to sputter and die, leaving behind a dead, grey void. The black corruption pulsed with a sickly, parasitic rhythm, the absolute antithesis of the healthy life-flow around it. And at its heart, where the rot was deepest and most concentrated, was a single, throbbing point of utter blackness. The map zoomed in, the perspective shifting with dizzying speed, the web of life giving way to a more familiar geography of concrete and steel. He saw a specific area of the city: a derelict industrial zone near the waterfront, a place of rusting railway spurs and abandoned warehouses. The focus narrowed further, to one specific building, a crumbling brick behemoth with a collapsed roof and boarded-up windows. That was it. The source. The heart of the blight. The stench of decay seemed to rise from the page, a phantom smell so potent he nearly gagged.

He snatched the stone off the page, and the light vanished, the map returning to a set of inert, cryptic lines on a fragile leaf. He shoved the stone back in his pocket, his hand shaking, his heart hammering. He had it. A location. He didn't know what he would do when he got there, but he knew where to go. He sat there for a moment, forcing his breathing to even out, keenly aware of the librarian’s gaze. He picked up the pencil, his hand still unsteady, and pretended to scribble a few meaningless notes on the paper, mimicking the posture of a diligent scholar. After a few minutes of this charade, he gently closed the ancient book, the earthy smell fading as the covers met. He took off the gloves, placed them neatly beside the book, and stood up, his legs feeling like jelly. He had his next breadcrumb, and it was leading him straight into the dark.## Chapter 2

Alistair returned the *Arborium Geographica* to the librarian with the careful, deliberate movements of a man handling unexploded ordnance. He slid the book cradle back across the polished desk, his own bare hands feeling brutish and unclean after the delicate, revelatory touch of the ancient pages. Ms. Sterling inspected the book without a word, her sharp eyes scanning the spine and cover for any sign of mishandling. Satisfied, she gave a curt nod and retrieved the burlap sack from a locker behind her desk, placing it on the counter between them. The formless black box within seemed to suck the warmth from the air, a pocket of pure void in the well-lit, scholarly room. "I hope you found the foundational connections you were looking for, Mr. Finch," she said, her tone perfectly neutral, yet her gaze held his for a fraction of a second too long. It was a look that felt less like a simple farewell and more like a quiet, unnerving assessment. Alistair simply nodded, unable to form a reply, and fled, the sack clutched in his hand, the oppressive silence of the archive clinging to him until he burst back out into the cacophony of the library's main hall.

The drive to the waterfront was a journey through a world that no longer felt entirely his own. The rusty Tacoma groaned and shuddered through the stop-and-go traffic of downtown, a familiar litany of mechanical complaints that now seemed trivial, almost nostalgic. Around him, the city pulsed with oblivious life. Businessmen shouted into phones, students laughed over coffee, buses hissed and rumbled past, each a tiny, self-contained drama playing out on a stage that Alistair now knew was rotting from below. The knowledge was a nauseating weight in his gut. The black box, shrouded in burlap on the seat beside him, seemed to mock the mundane reality of it all. He was Alistair Finch. His greatest battles were waged against spider mites and aphid infestations with neem oil and predatory insects. Now he was driving toward a cancerous node on the soul of the world, armed with a magic rock, a book he didn't understand, and a profound, bone-deep certainty that he was going to die.

He parked three blocks away from the address the vision had given him, the truck’s engine sputtering into a grateful silence. The change in atmosphere was immediate and stark. The vibrant hum of the city centre gave way to a deadened quiet, broken only by the mournful cry of a distant gull and the sighing of the wind through skeletal metal frameworks. This was a forgotten corner of the city, a graveyard of industry where warehouses slumped like tired giants and railway tracks rusted into orange oblivion. The air was thick with the smells of salt, creosote, and damp, crumbling concrete. And underneath it all, faint but unmistakable, was the other smell. The stench of Vex’s rot, a cloying sweetness like flowers decaying in stagnant water, an odour that made the fillings in Alistair’s teeth ache and the hairs on his arms stand on end. His senses, a grim compass needle, eventually led him to the heart of the town’s malaise: a small, paved square in front of the community hall. At its center stood a rough-hewn granite memorial, its surface bearing a bronze plaque listing the names of the town's war dead, from the Great War to Afghanistan. A small, neglected community garden bed surrounded its base, the soil sour and compacted, the few remaining plants blighted and withered. But the psychic poison wasn't coming from the soil. Alistair placed a hand on the cold bronze of the plaque, and the full, wretched nature of the sickness flooded him. The rot had sunk its tendrils into the town’s grief. It was feeding on the memory of sacrifice, twisting solemn remembrance into a festering, endless well of bitterness. It amplified the pain of loss until it overshadowed any pride, any honor. The plaque was no longer a monument to heroes; it had been turned into a focal point of grievance, a psychic abscess that constantly leaked a slow, subtle poison of resentment and victimhood into the town’s collective soul.

He stepped back, a new kind of horror dawning on him. This was Vex’s most insidious work yet. He hadn't sent a monster or a geological weapon; he had simply found a crack in a community’s heart and poured his poison in, letting them tear themselves apart. Alistair could not shatter this with the void; to do so would be an unthinkable desecration, an erasure of the very history the town was clinging to, however painfully. He could not simply jolt it with life; the grief was too deep, the wound too old. To heal this, he couldn’t be a warden or a warrior. He had to be a gardener in the truest sense of the word. He had to find a way to gently, patiently, untangle the roots of a healthy memory from the parasitic fungus of a corrupted grief. And he had to do it in a town that saw him as nothing more than a threat.## Chapter 10

Alistair retreated, melting back into the deepening twilight that pooled in the alleyways of Argent Falls. The cold bronze of the plaque felt like a brand on his palm, the town’s collective, curdled grief a poison he had tasted firsthand. He could not stay here, a visible anomaly in a town that had forgotten how to trust. He drove the Tacoma out to a deserted scenic lookout point just beyond the town limits, a place where tourists once stopped to admire the now-diminished waterfall. Here, under a sky vast and indifferent and bristling with cold, distant stars, he could think. He sat on the hood of his truck, the engine ticking as it cooled, and watched the scattered lights of the town, a small, wounded constellation in the immense darkness of the valley.

He could not simply destroy this infection. It was not a mindless beast or a geological weapon; it was a parasite intertwined with something sacred. To attack it with the void would be like using a flamethrower to remove a spider from a priceless painting. The collateral damage would be an act of desecration greater than the one Vex had already committed. No, this required a gardener’s touch. A weed is just a plant in the wrong place. The rot was feeding on grief, a powerful and necessary human emotion. He couldn’t eliminate the food source. He had to introduce a competitor, a healthier organism that could process the grief into something other than bitterness. He needed to plant something that would transform the sour soil of memory into a garden of remembrance.

He slid off the hood and went to the passenger side, opening the door and reaching for the black box. He placed it on the hood of the truck, the dark, featureless wood seeming to absorb the starlight. He did not ask it for a weapon. He came to it with a complex, delicate recipe. He opened the box and looked into its empty, velvet-lined interior. He needed a seed, but not one from the box’s strange arsenal. He needed a seed with a history, a seed that understood loss. He reached into his pocket and pulled out the small glass jar of soil from his nursery. He poured the dark, rich loam into the box, a handful of his own lost home. Then, with a pained hesitation, he took out the pressed monstera leaf from his field guide. It was a perfect, flattened memory of his old life, a symbol of the peaceful, green world he had sacrificed. He laid it carefully on top of the soil. This was his offering. His own grief, his own loss, laid bare upon the altar.

Finally, he held his hands over the box, closing his eyes, and began the most difficult piece of magic he had ever attempted. He called upon the green, the foundational power of life and growth, and poured it into the box, infusing the soil and the leaf with the pure concept of renewal, of life’s stubborn insistence on continuing. Then, with a shudder of revulsion, he summoned the black. But he did not use it as a weapon. He drew out the thinnest, most delicate thread of the void and used it not to unmake, but to hollow out. He shaped it into the idea of selfless sacrifice, of an empty space left behind by a noble absence. He wove the two threads together, life and loss, growth and sacrifice, a complex, painful harmony of opposites. He was not creating a prison or a bomb. He was creating a memory, given form. He poured his own aching sense of duty into the mixture, the sorrow of a shepherd who had to leave his flock. He pushed and shaped and wove until he was dizzy with the effort, sweat beading on his brow despite the mountain chill.

When he opened his eyes, the soil and the leaf were gone. In their place, nestled on the black velvet, were three seeds. They were shaped like teardrops, and they were the colour of dried blood, with a faint, silvery luminescence that pulsed with the slow, solemn rhythm of a sleeping heart. They were Seeds of Remembrance. He knew, with an intuitive certainty, that they would not grow into a monstrous warden or a plant of light. They would grow into flowers that fed on the complex chemistry of sorrow, drawing the poison of bitterness out of the soil and transforming it, through their own life cycle, into a quiet, solemn beauty. They would not erase the grief; they would give it a purpose, a place to go, a way to be beautiful again.

The act left him utterly spent, a hollowed-out echo of himself. But there was no time for rest. He had to plant them before the town’s suspicion could fully galvanize against him. He waited until the last lights in the valley had gone out, until the moon was high and the silence was broken only by the whisper of the wind. He drove the Tacoma back into town, parking it in a dark, overgrown alley, and made his way on foot to the community square, carrying the three seeds and a small trowel he had taken from his truck. The memorial stood in the moonlight, a somber block of shadow, radiating a cold that was more than just the night air.

He knelt in the neglected garden bed at its base, the sour, compacted earth resistant and dead under his hands. He began to work, his trowel scraping softly against stones, his movements quiet and efficient as he prepared three small holes for the seeds. He was so focused on his task, on the silent prayer he was forming in his mind, that he did not hear the footsteps approaching on the pavement behind him until a shadow fell over him.

"You have ten seconds to explain what you think you're doing to our memorial before I introduce your head to the pavement." The voice was low, gravelly, and utterly devoid of patience. Alistair froze, his hand hovering over the small hole he had just dug. He looked up slowly. The man standing over him was tall and broad, wearing a fleece-lined denim jacket and a weary expression that looked like it had been carved into his face over many hard years. There was no badge, but he had the unmistakable air of a man used to being in charge, of seeing the worst in people and usually being right.

Alistair rose slowly, his knees aching, his mind racing. The truth was an impossibility, a lie an insult. He looked from the man’s hard, tired eyes to the bronze plaque, then back. "This place is sick," Alistair said, his voice raspy from disuse. "The garden is dead. I'm a gardener. I'm trying to plant something that will live."

The man scoffed, a harsh, humorless sound. "It's dead because nobody cares anymore. And you look less like a gardener and more like a drifter looking to pry the bronze off for scrap. I know your kind." He took a step closer, his presence looming and threatening. "This is a sacred place. Whatever you're doing, you're done. Get out of my town."

Alistair didn't move. He held the man's gaze, letting him see the profound, unnatural weariness in his own eyes. "My grandfather's name is on a wall like this one, in a town a lot like this one," he lied, the falsehood coming to him not as a trick, but as a desperate bridge. "I know what a place like this is supposed to feel like. This doesn't feel like remembrance. It feels like a sickness. It feels like the sorrow has gone sour." The words hung in the cold night air, raw and surprisingly true. The man’s hard expression faltered for a fraction of a second. A flicker of pained recognition crossed his face before the mask of suspicion slammed back into place.

"You don't know anything about our sorrow," the man said, his voice dropping to a dangerous growl. But the conviction had a crack in it. He had felt it too. Alistair opened his hand, showing the man the three teardrop-shaped seeds, their faint, silvery light pulsing in his palm. "These aren't ordinary seeds," he said quietly. "They're for places like this. For when the grief gets too heavy. Let me plant them. If I'm wrong, they're just seeds. They won't grow. But if I'm right... maybe the garden won't be dead next spring."

The man stared at the strange, luminous seeds, then back at Alistair's haunted face. He was caught between a lifetime of cynical experience and the undeniable, aching truth of Alistair’s words. He was tired of the bitterness, of the poison that was slowly killing his home. He took a step back, a gesture of concession so small it was almost invisible. "You have five minutes," he said, his voice rough with resignation. "Then you're gone. And if I see you in this valley again after sunrise, we'll be having a very different conversation."

Without another word, Alistair knelt again, the unspoken truce hanging heavy and fragile in the moonlight. He gently placed one seed in each of the three holes he had prepared, his dirt-stained fingers performing a final, delicate rite. He covered them over with the sour soil, his hands moving with a lifetime of practice. There was no flash of light, no sudden change. There was only the quiet, patient, and hopeful act of planting a seed in the dark. He stood, gave the silent man a single, grateful nod, and walked away, disappearing back into the shadows from which he came, leaving behind three teardrops of hope buried at the heart of a town that had forgotten how to mourn. He was gone from the valley long before the first rays of the sun touched the high peaks, the outcome of his work a quiet prayer left to the slow, uncertain mercy of the earth.The Rocky Mountains were a wall at Alistair’s back, a fortress of silent stone he had defended and then abandoned. Ahead of him, the world flattened out and opened up, the tight valleys and towering peaks giving way to the vast, humbling expanse of the Canadian prairies. The sky was immense, a dome of pale, boundless blue that dwarfed everything beneath it, reducing the truck to a tiny, insignificant speck crawling across the bottom of a great, empty bowl. The change in the land brought a profound shift in the psychic geography Alistair now inhabited. The deep, slow song of the mountain’s stone was gone, replaced by the whisper of endless grass, the deep, sedimentary quiet of a thousand feet of ancient seabed, and the patient, enduring spirit of a land defined not by height, but by horizon.

He drove for a full day across the plains of southern Alberta, a relentless, hypnotic journey through a sea of gold and brown. The towns grew smaller and farther apart, lonely clusters of grain elevators and clapboard houses clinging to the railway lines like desperate survivors on a raft. Here, the web of life was different. It was a sprawling, horizontal network, less intricate than the tangled forests of the coast, but vast and deeply interconnected, a single, immense organism dreaming of sun and rain. But as he drove deeper into the heart of the continent, he began to feel a new texture to the sickness. It was not the angry, violent rot of the city, nor the quiet despair of the mountain town. It was a creeping numbness, a vast and spreading silence, the psychic equivalent of a region falling into a coma.

The feeling grew stronger until it was a constant, low thrum of wrongness on the edge of his senses. He finally pulled the Tacoma over to the side of a dead-straight highway that shot arrow-like towards the vanishing point. On either side, fields of wheat stretched to the horizon, a rolling, golden sea under the afternoon sun. It looked healthy, bountiful, the very picture of agricultural prosperity. But Alistair could feel the lie. He got out of the truck, the wind a constant, dry pressure against him, and walked to the edge of the nearest field. He pushed past the wire fence and stepped into the wheat. The stalks were tall and strong, the heads of grain heavy. But as he reached out and touched one, a chill ran up his arm. He stripped the husk away from the kernels with his thumb. They were not the pale, promising gold of healthy wheat. They were hard, perfectly formed beads of what looked like polished obsidian, each one containing a microscopic, pulsing point of malevolent, violet light.

He crushed one between his fingers. It didn’t crumble into floury dust; it shattered like glass, leaving behind a greasy, sterile black residue that smelled faintly of ozone and old electricity. He knelt and plunged his hand into the soil at the base of the stalks. It was bone-dry, powdery, and utterly dead. There were no worms, no beetles, no microbial life. The plants were not growing from the soil; they were feeding on it, consuming its life force and leaving behind sterile dust, all while producing a perfect, beautiful, and utterly toxic parody of sustenance. Alistair stood up, his gaze sweeping over the horizon, over the hundreds of square miles of golden, poisoned bounty. The sheer, logistical scale of this single act of corruption was staggering. This was not a random infection. This was a weapon of famine, patiently and brilliantly deployed.

He returned to the truck and laid his hand on the messenger stone. The map flared in his mind, and he saw the sickness, not as a stain, but as a deliberate, geometric pattern. The blighted fields formed a vast, interlocking sigil of decay, its lines drawn with dead soil and poisoned grain, a piece of dark calligraphy so enormous it could only be perceived from orbit, or by a man with a god’s-eye view. This was a new level of terrifying sophistication from Vex. This was not just a curse; it was a ritual. And at the precise, geographic center of the vast sigil, the stone showed him not a source of rot, but a single, stubbornly flickering point of pure, embattled green light. It was a tiny island of life in an ocean of sterilization, a defiant, living heart at the center of a web of death. A farmhouse. A person. The anchor.

Alistair’s jaw tightened. This was the next move in the game. He had been so focused on cleaning up the messes, he hadn’t considered that Vex might be using the infections for a larger purpose, weaving them into a continent-spanning spell. He started the truck, the quiet hum of its engine a stark contrast to the churning anger in his chest. He turned off the highway and onto a grid of dusty gravel roads, his course now set for the flickering light at the heart of the sigil. He was no longer just a wandering physician. He was a man with a map, driving toward a confrontation, not with another monster, but with the linchpin of his enemy's grand and terrible design. The lonely farmhouse appeared on the horizon hours later, a dark, angular shape against the immense, bleeding colours of the prairie sunset. It was a two-story clapboard structure, its paint scoured away by decades of wind and sun, leaving the wood a silvery, skeletal grey. It stood in a small depression, a shallow bowl in the vast flatness of the land, surrounded by a ragged circle of struggling cottonwoods, their leaves a defiant green against the encroaching gold of the blighted wheat. This small patch of land was the only place for a hundred miles that was not part of the sigil, an eye of defiant life in a hurricane of creeping death. As Alistair approached, he could feel the protective ward around the property, a thin, shimmering barrier of stubborn, weary magic, as tough and resilient as prairie grass.

He parked the Tacoma a quarter-mile away and walked the rest, not wanting the sound of his engine to be an alarm. The air grew subtly cleaner as he entered the circle of cottonwoods, the sterile, electric tang of the poisoned wheat giving way to the honest, earthy smell of living soil, sagebrush, and something else—the faint, sharp scent of woodsmoke and brewing herbs. The farmhouse itself was dark, no lights showing in the windows, but a thin plume of smoke curled from its crooked stone chimney, a single, fragile sign of life. A small, wild garden grew in messy patches around the house, a chaotic jumble of hardy perennials, native grasses, and medicinal herbs, each plant radiating a fierce, obstinate vitality. This was a garden that was not just growing; it was fighting.

Alistair stopped at the edge of the overgrown yard, a silent observer taking in the scene. He was a foreign body here, a carrier of both life and the void, and he knew his presence would be felt as a strange, dissonant chord in this place of pure, embattled green. He slowly raised a hand, not in greeting, but as a gesture of peace, and pushed a gentle, questioning pulse of his own green magic towards the silent house, a simple, non-verbal statement: *I am of the green. I am not the rot.*

The response was instantaneous and sharp, not a voice, but a psychic lash of pure, unadulterated suspicion. *The green in you is tainted. It walks with a shadow that has the taste of the void. You are a walking winter. State your purpose, or be scoured from this land.* The mental voice was old, dry as dust, and held the unyielding, abrasive strength of sandstone. Alistair felt the wards around the property tighten, the air growing thick and heavy with a pressure that was purely defensive. He had come here expecting to find a victim, an unwitting anchor for Vex’s spell. He had found a guardian, a warlock of a different tradition, as old and stubborn as the land itself.

"The shadow is a weapon, not a master," Alistair said, his own voice raspy in the quiet air, knowing he was being heard on more than one level. "I am here because of the sigil. The wheat. I am here because you are at the center of it, and I believe you know what it is."

The front door of the farmhouse creaked open, a dark rectangle in the deepening twilight. A figure emerged, a woman so old and weathered she seemed a part of the landscape itself. She was small and bird-like, wrapped in a thick wool shawl despite the mild evening, her face a roadmap of wrinkles, her eyes two chips of brilliant, intelligent obsidian. She held a gnarled cottonwood staff in one hand, and it hummed with a quiet, ancient power. She fixed him with a gaze that saw past his flannel shirt and tired face, right into the warring duality of his soul.

"I know what it is," she said, her voice a dry rustle of leaves. "It is the second verse of a song of ruin. The first was sung a century ago, and the third will be the end of all things that grow. I am Elara. And you, the man who walks with a hole in his soul, are the first new thing to happen in this land in a hundred years. You are either a fool who has stumbled into the heart of the storm, or you are the storm itself. I have not yet decided which. Come inside. The wind has ears tonight."
